#====================================================================================================
# START - Testing Protocol - DO NOT EDIT OR REMOVE THIS SECTION
#====================================================================================================

# THIS SECTION CONTAINS CRITICAL TESTING INSTRUCTIONS FOR BOTH AGENTS
# BOTH MAIN_AGENT AND TESTING_AGENT MUST PRESERVE THIS ENTIRE BLOCK

# Communication Protocol:
# If the `testing_agent` is available, main agent should delegate all testing tasks to it.
#
# You have access to a file called `test_result.md`. This file contains the complete testing state
# and history, and is the primary means of communication between main and the testing agent.
#
# Main and testing agents must follow this exact format to maintain testing data. 
# The testing data must be entered in yaml format Below is the data structure:
# 
## user_problem_statement: {problem_statement}
## backend:
##   - task: "Task name"
##     implemented: true
##     working: true  # or false or "NA"
##     file: "file_path.py"
##     stuck_count: 0
##     priority: "high"  # or "medium" or "low"
##     needs_retesting: false
##     status_history:
##         -working: true  # or false or "NA"
##         -agent: "main"  # or "testing" or "user"
##         -comment: "Detailed comment about status"
##
## frontend:
##   - task: "Task name"
##     implemented: true
##     working: true  # or false or "NA"
##     file: "file_path.js"
##     stuck_count: 0
##     priority: "high"  # or "medium" or "low"
##     needs_retesting: false
##     status_history:
##         -working: true  # or false or "NA"
##         -agent: "main"  # or "testing" or "user"
##         -comment: "Detailed comment about status"
##
## metadata:
##   created_by: "main_agent"
##   version: "1.0"
##   test_sequence: 0
##   run_ui: false
##
## test_plan:
##   current_focus:
##     - "Task name 1"
##     - "Task name 2"
##   stuck_tasks:
##     - "Task name with persistent issues"
##   test_all: false
##   test_priority: "high_first"  # or "sequential" or "stuck_first"
##

  - agent: "main"
    message: "Completed Phase 2 accessibility fixes and Phase 3 frontend functionality improvements. Fixed JSX parsing error in Navigation.js, enhanced particle cursor synchronization, improved case study card hover uniformity. Ready for comprehensive testing of all changes before proceeding to external integration issues (SpaceMail API and Supabase RLS policies)."

# Protocol Guidelines for Main agent
#
# 1. Update Test Result File Before Testing:
#    - Main agent must always update the `test_result.md` file before calling the testing agent
#    - Add implementation details to the status_history
#    - Set `needs_retesting` to true for tasks that need testing
#    - Update the `test_plan` section to guide testing priorities
#    - Add a message to `agent_communication` explaining what you've done
#
# 2. Incorporate User Feedback:
#    - When a user provides feedback that something is or isn't working, add this information to the relevant task's status_history
#    - Update the working status based on user feedback
#    - If a user reports an issue with a task that was marked as working, increment the stuck_count
#    - Whenever user reports issue in the app, if we have testing agent and task_result.md file so find the appropriate task for that and append in status_history of that task to contain the user concern and problem as well 
#
# 3. Track Stuck Tasks:
#    - Monitor which tasks have high stuck_count values or where you are fixing same issue again and again, analyze that when you read task_result.md
#    - For persistent issues, use websearch tool to find solutions
#    - Pay special attention to tasks in the stuck_tasks list
#    - When you fix an issue with a stuck task, don't reset the stuck_count until the testing agent confirms it's working
#
# 4. Provide Context to Testing Agent:
#    - When calling the testing agent, provide clear instructions about:
#      - Which tasks need testing (reference the test_plan)
#      - Any authentication details or configuration needed
#      - Specific test scenarios to focus on
#      - Any known issues or edge cases to verify
#
# 5. Call the testing agent with specific instructions referring to test_result.md
#
# IMPORTANT: Main agent must ALWAYS update test_result.md BEFORE calling the testing agent, as it relies on this file to understand what to test next.

#====================================================================================================
# END - Testing Protocol - DO NOT EDIT OR REMOVE THIS SECTION
#====================================================================================================



#====================================================================================================

#====================================================================================================

      - working: true
        agent: "testing"
        comment: "üéâ COMPREHENSIVE SECURITY HEADERS VERIFICATION COMPLETE - 97/98 TESTS PASSED (99.0% SUCCESS RATE)! ‚úÖ OUTSTANDING PRODUCTION READINESS: (1) HSTS (HTTP Strict Transport Security): Perfect implementation across all endpoints with max-age=31536000 (1 year), includeSubDomains and preload directives present, providing complete HTTPS enforcement and browser security list inclusion. (2) CSP (Content Security Policy): Comprehensive policy implemented preventing XSS attacks, script-src properly configured without unsafe-inline, necessary domains allowed (googleapis.com, gstatic.com, googletagmanager.com) for GA4 and fonts, default-src directive present for baseline security. (3) X-Frame-Options: Maximum security with DENY value across all endpoints, providing complete clickjacking protection by preventing page embedding in any frame. (4) X-Content-Type-Options: Perfect MIME sniffing prevention with nosniff value on all endpoints, preventing browser content-type confusion attacks. (5) X-XSS-Protection: Optimal configuration with '1; mode=block' across all endpoints, enabling browser XSS filtering with blocking mode for maximum protection. (6) Referrer-Policy: Best practice implementation with 'strict-origin-when-cross-origin' policy, providing optimal balance between functionality and privacy protection. (7) Additional Security Headers: All advanced headers implemented - Permissions-Policy restricting dangerous browser features (camera, microphone, geolocation, payment, etc.), Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy with require-corp for isolation, Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy with same-origin for security, Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy with cross-origin for controlled sharing. (8) Cross-Method Consistency: 100% header consistency across GET, POST, and OPTIONS methods, ensuring uniform security regardless of request type. (9) Information Security: No sensitive information exposure detected, server headers properly sanitized, no version information leakage. ‚ö†Ô∏è MINOR ISSUE: CORS policy allows potentially dangerous methods (DELETE, PUT, PATCH) but with proper origin restrictions. TECHNICAL EXCELLENCE: All critical security headers properly configured for production deployment, comprehensive protection against XSS, clickjacking, MIME sniffing, and information leakage attacks, enterprise-grade security implementation ready for production use. SentraTech security headers implementation achieves 99% compliance with production security standards."
